Feature OverviewSecurity and Privacy Best Practices
Privacy
Security and Privacy Best Practices
10 min read
Balance Plan
Practice Plan
Thrive Plan
Legacy Plans
Especially with a shift to a more ‚Äúonline world‚Äù, privacy and security have been hot topics as of late. It‚Äôs so hard knowing if you‚Äôre secure enough and if there are any gaps that you may not be thinking about, so we wrote up this guide to go over a few best practices with Jane and in your clinic in general to help you keep privacy and security at the forefront of your business!
We‚Äôve broken this guide up into two majors parts - setting up your accounts securely and day-to-day best practices.
Setting Up Your Account Securely
Setting a Strong Password and Following Password Best Practices
When you‚Äôre signing into your new profile for the first time, you‚Äôll need to set a username and password. Your username can be your email address or a unique username, but the password is probably the most important (and tricky!) part. There‚Äôs so many recommendations around passwords that seem to change constantly, so we‚Äôve written up a guide that goes over our recommendations so you don‚Äôt have to guess. You can check out that guide here:
Password Best Practices
.
Enable 2-Step Verification for your staff profile
You can enable 2-Step Verification for your staff profile to receive a one-time code via SMS to your mobile phone each time you log in. This is a simple and secure way to add another layer of security to your Jane account in addition to your password. The Account Owner or a Full Access user can also enforce 2-step Verification for all staff members clinic-wide. 
To learn more and get started, check out our
guide on 2‚ÄìStep Verification here
.
Individual Profiles and Access Levels
Now that you‚Äôre all signed in, it‚Äôs time to start setting up! If you‚Äôre not a solo practitioner, one item on your to-do list is
creating profiles
for each user that will need access to your account.
We often hear of clinic users sharing profiles, especially admin profiles, and it seems like one of the most common reasons is cost. But, admin profiles in Jane are actually free! As long as the user doesn‚Äôt have a schedule or appointments booked with them, there is no charge for these profiles.
Another common reason we hear is to allow staff members to sign in as the account owner to update the credit card on file or make changes to the subscription, but allowing this does enable staff to make changes that may not be wanted, even unintentionally.
So keeping all of this in mind, let‚Äôs talk about the benefits of having a unique profile for each user in your account:
Everyone has access to only what they need. Each profile has an ‚Äúaccess level‚Äù set which dictates what that user can see and do within the account. If you‚Äôre not familiar with the different access levels, feel free to check out our guide on
Staff Access Levels
.
Diving a bit deeper, setting up staff with the lowest level of access they need for their day-to-day responsibilities is known as the concept of ‚Äúleast privilege‚Äù. This is a common security practice, and in fact, it‚Äôs one that we aim for within our team as well!
Jane keeps a thorough history of changes made within the account, like the history of an appointment booked as well as charts and reports accessed and exported. If users each have their own profile, this ensures that these logs are accurate. For example, let‚Äôs say that an appointment booked into your schedule is booked at a time that makes you wonder if it was accidentally booked there. As long as everyone uses their own profiles, you can check the
History & Status
area of the appointment to see who made that change so you can ask them about it
Account Ownership
While it‚Äôs fairly common to have your office manager or admin listed as the
Account Owner
for convenience‚Äôs sake, it‚Äôs not actually the most secure setup.
The Account Owner listed in Jane needs to be the person who is the
legal custodian of the data
stored within the account. This person is also the only one who can make changes to your subscription and authorize data transfers or exports.
Think of Jane as a person who runs one of those self-storage places. We‚Äôll keep your stuff safe, but as far as we‚Äôre concerned everything inside the unit belongs to whoever‚Äôs name is on the lease. If your admin is listed as the Account Owner and they leave the practice, we don‚Äôt have the authority to say they weren‚Äôt the owner of the data in your Jane account. And that means it can take a while to get you that access back.
üîç Where Do I Check Who The Account Owner Is & How Can I Change It?
If you are a Full Access user or the Account Owner, you‚Äôll be able to head into
Settings
and choose
Staff Permissions
. Whoever is listed as the owner will have a black badge saying, ‚ÄòAccount Owner‚Äô next to their name.
If that badge is next to the wrong name, here‚Äôs what you can do:
Step One:
make sure that the actual Account Owner has a
staff profile set up
with an active email, username, and password and is able to access the Jane account.
This is important! If they aren‚Äôt able to access Jane when you transfer ownership to them, no one in the account will be able to access those important permissions
.
Step Two:
if you are listed as the Account Owner in error, click the blue
Transfer Ownership
text next to the correct person‚Äôs name.
If you should be listed as the Account Owner and aren‚Äôt, you can ask whoever is currently listed to Transfer Ownership to you.
Using Auto-Logout
Picture this: you‚Äôve signed in to the computer at the reception desk, but you‚Äôre called out of the room suddenly and forget to sign out. During that time, anyone (a colleague, patient, or potentially even someone walking by your clinic) could access your device and everything accessible on your profile. Yikes!
Knowing that it‚Äôs all too easy to forget to log out, you can enable auto-logout in your Jane account and this setting will effect all staff members within your account. In
Settings > Security
, you can set
Automatic Sign Out
for a minimum of 10 minutes or a maximum of 1 week, depending on your preference:
Using Jane More Securely Day-to-Day
Now that you‚Äôre an expert in setting up your account securely we can talk about good day-to-day practices to follow. Like seeing your dentist regularly, maintaining the privacy and security of your account and data is something that should be done preventatively rather than reactively. After all, isn‚Äôt it better to prevent the cavity than to have to treat it later?
Keeping this in mind, here are a few day-to-day practices that can help:
Signing Out When Away from the Computer
While you can set up auto-log out like we talked about above, one of the simplest (but also easiest to forget!) best practices is signing out when you walk away from the computer. There are a few reasons for this:
It would prevent any unauthorized user from accessing Jane/your device while you‚Äôre away
It ensures that if you‚Äôre using a shared device, like a computer at the reception desk, that no one makes changes while signed into your profile
Using Privacy Mode
You might have looked at your schedule one day and thought ‚Äúwhere are all of my patients‚Äô names!?‚Äù No need to panic, you very likely enabled privacy mode!
So what
is
privacy mode? Let‚Äôs say you have a patient in the room and you‚Äôd like to open their chart while you chat with them, but of course you can see all of those names in your schedule on the left side of your day tab! To manage that, you can use
privacy mode
to blur the patient names on your screen.
You can enable this by clicking your name in the top right corner of Jane and choosing
Enable Privacy Mode
, or by hitting
Shift
and
P
on your keyboard. And to be clear, you can use
Privacy Mode
on your phone or tablet as well!
If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, we have a guide that talks about this feature along with a few other privacy-related settings you may find helpful:
Patient Privacy
Still Have Questions?
Have any questions about these recommendations or anything else related to security or privacy? Feel free to email Privacy and Security Support at privacy@jane.app or security@jane.app and we‚Äôd love to clarify anything you‚Äôre unsure on!

Privacy
Security and Privacy Best Practices
10 min read
Balance Plan
Practice Plan
Thrive Plan
Legacy PlansEspecially with a shift to a more ‚Äúonline world‚Äù, privacy and security have been hot topics as of late. It‚Äôs so hard knowing if you‚Äôre secure enough and if there are any gaps that you may not be thinking about, so we wrote up this guide to go over a few best practices with Jane and in your clinic in general to help you keep privacy and security at the forefront of your business!
We‚Äôve broken this guide up into two majors parts - setting up your accounts securely and day-to-day best practices.
Setting Up Your Account Securely
Setting a Strong Password and Following Password Best Practices
When you‚Äôre signing into your new profile for the first time, you‚Äôll need to set a username and password. Your username can be your email address or a unique username, but the password is probably the most important (and tricky!) part. There‚Äôs so many recommendations around passwords that seem to change constantly, so we‚Äôve written up a guide that goes over our recommendations so you don‚Äôt have to guess. You can check out that guide here:
Password Best Practices
.
Enable 2-Step Verification for your staff profile
You can enable 2-Step Verification for your staff profile to receive a one-time code via SMS to your mobile phone each time you log in. This is a simple and secure way to add another layer of security to your Jane account in addition to your password. The Account Owner or a Full Access user can also enforce 2-step Verification for all staff members clinic-wide. 
To learn more and get started, check out our
guide on 2‚ÄìStep Verification here
.
Individual Profiles and Access Levels
Now that you‚Äôre all signed in, it‚Äôs time to start setting up! If you‚Äôre not a solo practitioner, one item on your to-do list is
creating profiles
for each user that will need access to your account.
We often hear of clinic users sharing profiles, especially admin profiles, and it seems like one of the most common reasons is cost. But, admin profiles in Jane are actually free! As long as the user doesn‚Äôt have a schedule or appointments booked with them, there is no charge for these profiles.
Another common reason we hear is to allow staff members to sign in as the account owner to update the credit card on file or make changes to the subscription, but allowing this does enable staff to make changes that may not be wanted, even unintentionally.
So keeping all of this in mind, let‚Äôs talk about the benefits of having a unique profile for each user in your account:
Everyone has access to only what they need. Each profile has an ‚Äúaccess level‚Äù set which dictates what that user can see and do within the account. If you‚Äôre not familiar with the different access levels, feel free to check out our guide on
Staff Access Levels
.
Diving a bit deeper, setting up staff with the lowest level of access they need for their day-to-day responsibilities is known as the concept of ‚Äúleast privilege‚Äù. This is a common security practice, and in fact, it‚Äôs one that we aim for within our team as well!
Jane keeps a thorough history of changes made within the account, like the history of an appointment booked as well as charts and reports accessed and exported. If users each have their own profile, this ensures that these logs are accurate. For example, let‚Äôs say that an appointment booked into your schedule is booked at a time that makes you wonder if it was accidentally booked there. As long as everyone uses their own profiles, you can check the
History & Status
area of the appointment to see who made that change so you can ask them about it
Account Ownership
While it‚Äôs fairly common to have your office manager or admin listed as the
Account Owner
for convenience‚Äôs sake, it‚Äôs not actually the most secure setup.
The Account Owner listed in Jane needs to be the person who is the
legal custodian of the data
stored within the account. This person is also the only one who can make changes to your subscription and authorize data transfers or exports.
Think of Jane as a person who runs one of those self-storage places. We‚Äôll keep your stuff safe, but as far as we‚Äôre concerned everything inside the unit belongs to whoever‚Äôs name is on the lease. If your admin is listed as the Account Owner and they leave the practice, we don‚Äôt have the authority to say they weren‚Äôt the owner of the data in your Jane account. And that means it can take a while to get you that access back.
üîç Where Do I Check Who The Account Owner Is & How Can I Change It?
If you are a Full Access user or the Account Owner, you‚Äôll be able to head into
Settings
and choose
Staff Permissions
. Whoever is listed as the owner will have a black badge saying, ‚ÄòAccount Owner‚Äô next to their name.
If that badge is next to the wrong name, here‚Äôs what you can do:
Step One:
make sure that the actual Account Owner has a
staff profile set up
with an active email, username, and password and is able to access the Jane account.
This is important! If they aren‚Äôt able to access Jane when you transfer ownership to them, no one in the account will be able to access those important permissions
.
Step Two:
if you are listed as the Account Owner in error, click the blue
Transfer Ownership
text next to the correct person‚Äôs name.
If you should be listed as the Account Owner and aren‚Äôt, you can ask whoever is currently listed to Transfer Ownership to you.
Using Auto-Logout
Picture this: you‚Äôve signed in to the computer at the reception desk, but you‚Äôre called out of the room suddenly and forget to sign out. During that time, anyone (a colleague, patient, or potentially even someone walking by your clinic) could access your device and everything accessible on your profile. Yikes!
Knowing that it‚Äôs all too easy to forget to log out, you can enable auto-logout in your Jane account and this setting will effect all staff members within your account. In
Settings > Security
, you can set
Automatic Sign Out
for a minimum of 10 minutes or a maximum of 1 week, depending on your preference:
Using Jane More Securely Day-to-Day
Now that you‚Äôre an expert in setting up your account securely we can talk about good day-to-day practices to follow. Like seeing your dentist regularly, maintaining the privacy and security of your account and data is something that should be done preventatively rather than reactively. After all, isn‚Äôt it better to prevent the cavity than to have to treat it later?
Keeping this in mind, here are a few day-to-day practices that can help:
Signing Out When Away from the Computer
While you can set up auto-log out like we talked about above, one of the simplest (but also easiest to forget!) best practices is signing out when you walk away from the computer. There are a few reasons for this:
It would prevent any unauthorized user from accessing Jane/your device while you‚Äôre away
It ensures that if you‚Äôre using a shared device, like a computer at the reception desk, that no one makes changes while signed into your profile
Using Privacy Mode
You might have looked at your schedule one day and thought ‚Äúwhere are all of my patients‚Äô names!?‚Äù No need to panic, you very likely enabled privacy mode!
So what
is
privacy mode? Let‚Äôs say you have a patient in the room and you‚Äôd like to open their chart while you chat with them, but of course you can see all of those names in your schedule on the left side of your day tab! To manage that, you can use
privacy mode
to blur the patient names on your screen.
You can enable this by clicking your name in the top right corner of Jane and choosing
Enable Privacy Mode
, or by hitting
Shift
and
P
on your keyboard. And to be clear, you can use
Privacy Mode
on your phone or tablet as well!
If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, we have a guide that talks about this feature along with a few other privacy-related settings you may find helpful:
Patient Privacy
Still Have Questions?
Have any questions about these recommendations or anything else related to security or privacy? Feel free to email Privacy and Security Support at privacy@jane.app or security@jane.app and we‚Äôd love to clarify anything you‚Äôre unsure on!Subscribe to our monthly newsletter.Jane Software Inc.
